title: Monitor Dehydration in Cold Weather
brief: Use urine color on snow to check hydration levels in cold environments.
steps: Step 1: Urinate on white snow to check hydration status.
Step 2: If urine makes snow dark yellow, you are becoming dehydrated and need fluids.
Step 3: If urine makes snow light yellow to no color, fluid balance is normal.
Step 4: Drink water regularly - need for water is as great in cold as warm environments.
Step 5: Be aware that heavy clothing absorbs moisture you lose, masking dehydration.
warnings: Cold weather can mask dehydration symptoms.
Exposure to cold increases urine output, further depleting body fluids.
Bundled clothing absorbs evaporated moisture, making water loss less obvious.
